text:
Would there be any interest in an "open problems in Julia"-session. An open problem would be something the presenter has researched and tried what she/he can but got stuck.
The session would work like this:
The presenter would start presenting 2 or 3 problems to set the tone and have different people commenting on it. The chair would ask if anyone has other open problems, other people get a chance to comment and this is repeated until the time scheduled is open. Each presenter would have a time limit to ensure that a wide variety of problems can be hurd

The open problems could range from compiler work to web dev. The only constraint is that the session is not <#C6A044SQH|helpdesk> and targets advanced Julia users.

text: Since there was absolutely no feedback on this i take that it was a bad idea.

text: To me it sounds a bit too open ended and the people attending would have no idea if the problems other people have are relevant to them. The wonderful <@U89GY9W1J> presented a talk that in 2019 that was kind of like this: he had done a lot of work on the problem but it was still at least partially open. <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JCFej--XER0>

text:
:heart: haha thanks for the kind words Travis!

Yeah I think that was a useful format! I think people should be encouraged to submit a talk or a lightning talk with their open problems and then they can be discussed afterwards

elements.text:
haha thanks for the kind words Travis!

Yeah I think that was a useful format! I think people should be encouraged to submit a talk or a lightning talk with their open problems and then they can be discussed afterwards

text: ^oh, the reason I mentioned the talk though is that I think it'd be fine to present open questions as their own (lightning) talks. I'm in no way involved with the review process but can't hurt, right?
